awd_titl_txt: EAGER: CRA-W Programs for Partnerships in the BPCnet Pilot
awd_abstract_narration:
The Computing Research Association's Committee on the Status of Women in Computing Research (CRA-W) proposes a project to pilot mechanisms that allow individual computer science and engineering (CSE) researchers to partner with its most successful flagship programs: Distributed Research Experiences for Undergraduates (DREU), Collaborative Research Experiences for Undergraduates (CREU), and Discipline-Specific Workshops (DSWs). These programs have helped to increase the numbers and successes of women and members of underrepresented groups who earn advanced degrees and pursue CSE research careers in academia, industry, or national labs.  To date, they have been run with a relatively small group of dedicated volunteers from the CSE research community. Now CRA-W aims to expand the reach of those programs by involving more CSE researchers as partners. The proposal is in response to and in alignment with the effort undertaken by the Computer and Information Systems and Engineering (CISE) Directorate to increase and support the broadening participation in computing (BPC) activities among more of its awardees (NSF DCL 17-110).

CRA-W's DREU, CREU and DSW programs have operated successfully and at-scale for many years. This work will engage a broader set of CISE-funded researchers in their operation. A researcher on a CISE-funded project , for example, could partner to send and/or receive a DREU student for a summer research project, or to support a CREU research team from their own university or a neighboring university, college or community college, or to host or contribute in some substantive way to the organization of a new DSW. This project will prepare the programs and their operational infrastructure (e.g. applications and management software) for the greater scale (both operationally and in terms of evaluation) that the new CISE effort is expected to require.

This award is co-funded by NSF INCLUDES, which focuses on catalyzing the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) enterprise to collaboratively work for inclusive change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The EAGER: CRA-W Programs for Partnerships in the BPCnet Pilot project, facilitated by the Computing Research Association, embarked on a mission to democratize the field of computing research. Spanning five years from October 2018 to September 2023, its core mission was to amplify the presence and achievements of underrepresented groups within computing. This expansive goal catered to a spectrum of individuals including women, underrepresented minorities, LGBTQ+ groups, and persons with disabilities, targeting their inclusion and success across all tiers of the research pipeline.

In alignment with the Social Cognitive Career Theory, the project's strategic initiatives focused on enhancing outcome expectations, self-efficacy, and social supports. This triad aimed to cultivate a robust interest in computing careers, thereby ensuring a nurturing environment for underrepresented groups to thrive within the field. Programs were thoughtfully designed to cater to a wide range of career stages, from undergraduates embarking on their academic journey to seasoned professionals at the pinnacle of their careers. Each initiative was a stepping stone towards making the computing research domain a more inclusive and equitable space.

One of the project's cornerstone activities was the in-depth evaluation and upgrade of program infrastructures. This was pivotal for scaling operations in conjunction with the expansion of the BPCnet Resource Portal, thereby broadening its reach within the computing community. The establishment of a Strategic Assessment and Redesign Committee (SARC) underscored the project's commitment to continuous improvement, ensuring that programs remained relevant and impactful.

Among the array of initiatives, the Collaborative and Distributed Research Experiences for Undergraduates (CREU and DREU) stood out. These programs were meticulously designed to offer undergraduates from underrepresented groups enriching research experiences. CREU facilitated team-based research projects during the academic year, fostering collaboration and innovation, while DREU provided summer research opportunities under the mentorship of faculty across the United States. These experiences were instrumental in building the participants' research acumen, confidence, and aspirations towards graduate studies.

The Discipline-Specific Workshops (DSW) were another innovative facet of the project, tailored to provide mentoring and build communities within specific sub-disciplines of computing. These workshops delved into the nuances of discipline-specific research, offering insights into publication norms, funding avenues, and emerging research topics. This initiative was particularly beneficial in providing technical knowledge and fostering a sense of belonging among underrepresented groups.

As the project navigated through challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic, it exhibited remarkable adaptability. The transition to virtual formats for DREU was a testament to the project's resilience, ensuring the continuity of research experiences amidst global disruptions. The enhancement of the DREU infrastructure within the CadmiumCD platform marked a significant leap towards efficient program management and communication.

The Graduate Cohort Workshop for Women (GC-Women) was another highlight, aiming to bolster the ranks of senior women in computing. This workshop provided a platform for women in the early to later stages of their graduate studies to gain insights on navigating graduate school, planning their careers, and networking. The transition back to onsite programs post-pandemic was a significant milestone, allowing for richer, in-person interactions and networking opportunities.

The project's impact was evident in the significant results achieved over the years. The relaunch of the CREU and DREU programs with improved infrastructures, increased participation in workshops, and the successful transition back to onsite activities post-pandemic were commendable achievements. Participant evaluations reflected high levels of satisfaction with the content and networking opportunities provided, underscoring the project's effectiveness in meeting its objectives.

Training and professional development opportunities were a hallmark of the project, directly engaging participants in research projects and facilitating interactions with mentors and the broader research community. This hands-on approach was instrumental in preparing participants for advanced studies and careers in computing.

The dissemination of the project's outcomes and activities was comprehensive, leveraging organizational websites, social media, electronic newsletters, and BPC meetings. This ensured that the project's impacts and learnings were shared widely, inspiring similar initiatives and contributing to the broader goal of widening participation in computing research.

EAGER: CRA-W Programs for Partnerships in the BPCnet Pilot has been a beacon of inclusivity and empowerment in the computing research community. Through its diverse range of programs and initiatives, the project has significantly contributed to widening participation and improving access, opportunities, and experiences for underrepresented groups in computing research and education.
